case_name: Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd., Bombay v. Workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 321 of 1958 filed by Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 321 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated the

facts.text: Appeal by special leave against Award dated September 27, 1957 of Industrial Tribunal, Bombay in Reference No. 119 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated the September 27, 1957 of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference T.  No. 119 of 1957.

facts.text: Dispute referred to Industrial Tribunal by Government of Bombay order dated June 18, 1957

anchor.surface_text: This dispute was referred to the Industrial Tribunal by the Government of Bombay by its order dated June 18, 1957.

facts.text: Company paid 2.5 months basic wages as bonus for 1955-56

anchor.surface_text: The companypany had already paid 21 months basic wages as bonus to its workmen and the real dispute was thus only about the remaining

facts.text: Workmen demanded bonus equivalent to four months wages/salary for employees drawing less than Rs. 500 per month for 1955-56

anchor.surface_text: The dispute arose over a demand made by the workmen for payment unconditionally as bonus for the year 1955-56 of a sum equivalent to four months wages salary for all employees drawing wages salary of less than Rs. 500 per menses.

facts.text: Company made record profits in 1955-56 and declared 12% dividend free of income-tax

anchor.surface_text: The case of the workmen was that the companypany had made record profits during the year and declared a dividend of 12 per centum free of income-tax,

facts.text: Company started business in 1917, shareholders began receiving dividends from 1940

anchor.surface_text: It was also pointed out that though the companypany started as far back as 1917, the shareholders began to get dividends only from 1940,

facts.text: Company claimed exclusion of six items of extraneous income totaling Rs. 4.12 lacs

anchor.surface_text: Six items were sought to be excluded by the companypany as extraneous income, and they were these In lacs Rs. Income earned by way of rent, light and power0-24 Estate Revenue 0-08 Profit on sale of empty barrels 0-89 Excess provision for expenses in the previous year 0-31 Refund of income-tax on revision of Cochin assessment of Excess Profits Tax 0-49 Sale proceeds of tin cans, scraps, logs, planks, gunnies c. 2-11 Total 4-12

facts.text: Profit of Rs. 3 lacs in accounts due to change in method of valuation

anchor.surface_text: Next it claimed that a profit of Rs. 3 lacs appearing in the accounts due to the change in the method of valuation was numberreal profit due to the efforts of labour

facts.text: Company claimed entitlement to 4% interest on working capital including depreciation fund

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it also claimed that it was entitled to 4 per centum interest on the working capital, including the amount in the depreciation fund.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal disallowed company's claims on extraneous income, Rs.3 lacs profit, and working capital interest, awarded 3.5 months bonus

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal disallowed the claim of the companypany on all these three points and after making relevant calculations came to the companyclusion that there was a sufficient surplus available to permit the grant of bonus for 3-1/2 months calculated on basic wages and therefore awarded the same.

facts.text: Items iv and v of extraneous income conceded by workmen (excess provision Rs.0.31 lac, refund income-tax Rs.0.49 lac)

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the respondents appearing before us has stated that the claim with respect to items  iv  and  v  was companyceded by the workmen before the Tribunal

facts.text: Supreme Court excludes Rs.3 lacs profit as extraneous income

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal did number accept this income as extraneous and in so doing it fell into error. This income of Rs. 3 lacs has numberhing whatsoever to do with the efforts of labour,

facts.text: Supreme Court accepts working capital as Rs.139.09 lacs including depreciation reserve based on unchallenged affidavit

anchor.surface_text: So far therefore as the present year is companycerned, we must accept the affidavit and hold that the working capital was Rs. 139.09 lacs.

facts.text: Available surplus calculated as Rs.7.63 lacs after adjustments

anchor.surface_text: Available surplus 7-63 Less bonus actually paid 7-90 Less rebate of income-tax at 3-40 -/7/- in the rupee 4-50 Amount remaining with the Company 3-13

facts.text: Company already paid bonus of Rs.7.90 lacs (2.5 months), entitled to income-tax rebate of Rs.3.40 lacs

anchor.surface_text: The companypany has, already paid 2-1/2 months bonus amounting to Rs. 7-90 lacs to the workmen. The companypany would be entitled to a rebate of Rs. 3-40 lacs on this sum

facts.text: Judgment delivered on May 5, 1959 by WANCHOO J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. May 5. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the award of the Industrial Tribunal,

facts.text: Company pays graded scale of wages with annual and biennial increments

anchor.surface_text: The companypany, on the other hand, companytended that it was paying graded scale of wages with annual and biennial increments and had already paid profit bonus for 2-1/2 months.

facts.text: Tribunal included all six extraneous income items in calculations despite some not disputed

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal rejected the claim with respect to all these items, though in the judgment it mentioned only items  i ,  ii ,  iii  and  vi  as those in dispute.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds four items of income (rent/light/power Rs.0.24, estate revenue 0.08, empty barrels 0.89, scraps etc. 2.11) are not extraneous

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefor, of opinion that all these four items were rightly taken into account by the Tribunal in arriving at the gross. profits.

facts.text: Company used depreciation reserve as part of working capital Rs.139.09 lacs

anchor.surface_text: An affidavit was made on behalf of the companypany that it had used its reserve funds companyprising premium on ordinary shares, general reserve, depreciation reserve,

facts.text: Tribunal allowed 4% return on working capital of Rs.31.88 lacs excluding depreciation reserve

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, however, allowed return at 4 per centum on a working capital of Rs. 31.88 lacs. This excluded the depreciation reserve but included all other reserves

facts.text: Gross profits for 1955-56 Rs.49.55 lacs

anchor.surface_text: Gross Profits. 49-55 Less extraneous income 3-80 Balance 45-75

facts.text: Court sets aside Tribunal award and dismisses claim for bonus beyond 2.5 months already paid

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, allow the appeal, set aside the order of the Industrial Tribunal and dismiss the claim of the workmen for any bonus beyond what has already been granted by the companypany.

issues.text: Whether the six items of income sought to be excluded by the company qualify as extraneous income and should not be taken into account for the purposes of the Full Bench formula

holdings.text: income arising during the year in the normal course of business of the concern can not be called extraneous income merely on the ground that no direct connection between the efforts of labour and the accrual of the income has been established

anchor.surface_text: But apart from these cases, we cannot see how income arising during the year in the numbermal companyrse of business of the companycern can be called extraneous income merely on the ground that numberdirect companynection between the efforts of labour and the accrual of the income has been established.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Joint contribution of capital and labour to normal business profits suffices; direct nexus per item not required per Muir Mills; extraneous only if not earned that year, fortuitous/unconnected to labour, or from fixed assets

precedents.citation: The Mill-Owners Association, Bombay v. The Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: The Mill-Owners Association, Bombay v. The Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay 1 in which the Full Bench formula was evolved, the appellate tribunal remarked at page 1257 No scheme of allocation of bonus companyld be companyplete if the amount out of which a bonus is to be paid is unrelated to employees efforts.

precedents.case_name: Mill-Owners Association, Bombay v. Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: No scheme of allocation of bonus could be complete if the amount out of which a bonus is to be paid is unrelated to employees efforts
precedents.cited_holding: No scheme of allocation of bonus could be complete if the amount out of which a bonus is to be paid is unrelated to employees efforts

precedents.citation: Shalimar Rope Works Mazdoor Union, Howrah v. Messrs. Shalimar Rope Works Ltd., Shalimar, Howah 2

anchor.surface_text: Shalimar Rope Works Mazdoor Union, Howrah v. Messrs. Shalimar Rope Works Ltd., Shalimar, Howah 2 by observing at page 372 that it is however too late in the day to question the view that there are profits unrelated to workers efforts and referred to as extraneous profits

precedents.case_name: Shalimar Rope Works Mazdoor Union, Howrah v. Shalimar Rope Works Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: profits unrelated to workers efforts and referred to as extraneous profits must be left out of account in deciding available surplus
precedents.cited_holding: it is however too late in the day to question the view that there are profits unrelated to workers efforts and referred to as extraneous profits and that such profits must be left out of account

precedents.case_name: Muir Mills Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mills Mazdoor Union, Kanpur
precedents.cited_proposition: two conditions for bonus demand: wages fall short of living standard and industry makes huge profits part of which due to workmen contribution in increasing production
precedents.cited_holding: There are however two conditions which have to be satisfied before a demand for bonus can be justified, and they are, (1) when wages fall short of the living standard and (2) the industry makes huge profits part of which are due to the contribution which the workmen make in increasing production
